intro: Dysophylla pentagona, commonly known as the five-angled dysophylla, is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family. It is a perennial herb characterized by its distinctive pentagonal leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, clustered yellowish-green flowers, which are typically surrounded by modified leaves called cyathia. Dysophylla pentagona is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa and is often found in moist, shaded environments. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and taxonomic studies.
